title: Homemade Kimchi

ingredients.name: onion (1 large per 2 heads of cabbage)

steps: Brine the cabbage: Quarter napa cabbage lengthwise. Dissolve a generous amount of coarse sea salt in water. Submerge cabbage in salt water and place a weight on top to keep it submerged.
Let brine for 6 hours, turning the cabbage a couple times during brining. The cabbage should be very salty when you taste it - don't worry, it will be rinsed.
After 6 hours, rinse the cabbage thoroughly under cold water to remove salt. The cabbage should bend without breaking when properly brined. Let drain completely.
Make the paste base: Blend Korean pear, onion (1 large onion per 2 heads of cabbage), garlic, and ginger until smooth.
Make glutinous rice flour mixture: Mix glutinous rice flour with water and beef stock powder. Cook until thickened, then cool completely.
Mix the paste: Combine the blended pear mixture, cooled rice flour mixture, gochugaru (use high quality Korean gochugaru like Nongshim brand), fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, and a tiny bit of MSG.
Add chopped spring onions to the paste.
If making radish kimchi, divide the paste and add radish sticks to one portion.
Wearing gloves, coat each cabbage leaf thoroughly with the paste, working from the outer leaves inward.
Pack the kimchi tightly into clean jars or containers. Press down to remove air pockets.
Let ferment at room temperature for 1-3 days depending on desired sourness, then refrigerate.
Kimchi will continue to ferment slowly in the refrigerator and develop flavor over time.
notes: Recipe adapted from Maangchi and Baek Jongwon's methods
The key to good kimchi is generous salting - the cabbage should taste too salty before rinsing
Use high-quality Korean gochugaru (not Chinese substitutes) for best flavor and color - Nongshim brand recommended
Korean pear adds natural sweetness and is healthier than adding extra sugar
Measurements are intentionally flexible - adjust to taste as you go
